name: Word Origins from Literature Quiz / Test | Literary Terms & Quotes | 10 Questions

questions.text: The term 'gargantuan' finds its origin in the fictional character of the same name. Who was the author?
questions.explanation:
Rabelais.

	Rabelais - who gives rise to the term 'Rabelaisian' for one who is somewhat coarse.

questions.text: The idea of 'Shangri-la' has been accepted into the vocabulary. Who wrote the novel that popularized this fictional place?
questions.explanation:
James Hilton.

	'Lost Horizon' was the novel.

questions.text: 'Babbitt' refers to someone who is middle class - in a stuffy, unoriginal way. Who wrote the novel of the same name?
questions.explanation:
Sinclair Lewis.

	Lewis also wrote 'Arrowsmith' and 'Main Street' and picked up a Nobel Prize.

questions.text: The term 'Shylock ' has come to have an everyday usage. In which of Shakespeare's plays does this character appear?
questions.explanation:
Merchant of Venice.

	One of the bard's most famous characters.

questions.text: 'Lilliputian' refers to something quite small. What author wrote about Lilliput?
A 'misanthrope' is a sour type of person. Who wrote the work of the same name?
The term 'Micawber' is often used to describe a person with a certain type of attitude. In which book by Charles Dickens does the character appear?
We commonly speak about Faust; who wrote the tragedy of 'Doctor Faustus'?
questions.explanation:
Christopher Marlowe.

	One of his best known plays.

questions.text: In psychology, one theorist has described what he calls an 'Icarus complex', based on the mythological character, Icarus. Who was the father of this mythological figure?
questions.explanation:
Daedalus.

	He flew too high and crashed into the sea after the sun melted his wax wings - careless!

questions.text: We often speak of people who are 'quixotic' or 'tilt at windmills'. Who is the author involved?
